title: 111_hr6309
content: The Act may be cited as the "Notification of Origin of Telecommunications and Internet Consumer Exchanges Act of 2010" or the "NOTICE Act of 2010". Definitions are provided in Section 2. In this Act, "business entity" refers to any organization established for profit through commerce in the United States. "Commerce" is defined as in the Consumer Product Safety Act. A "consumer" is an individual in the US who purchases goods or services for personal use. "Customer service communication" is any communication between a consumer and a business entity in commerce. Telecommunication refers to the transmission of chosen information without alteration, while wire communication involves the transmission of various forms of data through wire connections. Business entities engaged in customer service communications must disclose their physical location as required by SEC. 3. Business entities must disclose their physical location at the beginning of customer service communications, with exceptions for US-based entities and communications initiated by consumers to foreign entities. Business entities must disclose their physical location at the beginning of customer service communications, with exceptions for US-based entities and communications initiated by consumers to foreign entities. The Federal Trade Commission may exclude certain classes of business entities from these requirements if exceptionally compelling circumstances justify it. Each year, businesses participating in customer service communications must certify their compliance to the FTC. Regulations must be established within one year of the effective date. The Federal Trade Commission must create regulations within one year of the enactment of the Act to enforce its provisions. The requirements for disclosing physical location in customer service communications will apply one year after the Act's enactment date. SEC. 4. ENFORCEMENT. Any failure to comply with the provisions of section 3 of the Act will be treated as a violation of a regulation under the Federal Trade Commission Act regarding unfair or deceptive acts or practices. The Federal Trade Commission has the power to prevent violations of the Act and its regulations, with penalties and privileges similar to those under the Federal Trade Commission Act. The provisions of the Commission Act are incorporated into this Act, preserving the authority of the Federal Trade Commission under any other law.
